General.text:
Type:
Vasopressors
Dosage Forms:
Concentration
Amount of solution in mL used to dilute 1,000mg of epinephrine
eg 1:10,000 = 1,000mg/10,000mL = 0.1mg/mL
Common Trade Names: Adrenaline, EpiPen (IM autoinjector)

Anaphylaxis.text:
0.3-0.5mg of 1:1,000 IM
Consider
glucagon
1-5mg IV if patient on beta-blockers and not responding to epi

Anaphylactic_shock.text: 0.1mg of 1:10,000 slow IV during 5 min, can start infusion of 1-4 mcg/min

Quick_Epi_Drip.text: Take your code-cart epinephrine (it does not matter if It is 1:1,000 or 1:10,000) and inject 1mg into a liter bag of NS. Final concentration is 1mcg/ml. Run at 1cc/min and titrate to effect.

Pulseless_Arrest.text:
0.01 mg/kg (1:10,000 solution) IV/IO q3-5 min
Max: 1mg/dose

Anaphylaxis_2.text:

Max: 0.3 mg/dose in pre-pubertal patients; 0.5 mg/dose in teenage patients
May repeat dose q5-15 min x 2

Adverse_Reactions.text:
Tachyarrhythmias
Myocardial ischemia
Increased serum lactate
Splanchnic ischemia
Digital EpiPen injection

Pharmacology.text:
Onset of action: 1-2 minutes (IV), 8-10 minutes (IM)
Half-life: < 5 minutes (IV)
[2]
, 45 minutes (IM)
Metabolism: Hepatic
Excretion: Renal
Mechanism of action: potent α and β agonist that increases cardiac output and peripheral vascular resistance

Dose-dependent_effects.text:
1-10 mcg/min - increase HR and SV ("inotropic" epinephrine)
10-20 mcg/min - increase SVR

Notes.text:
↑lactate occurs primarily from ↑glycolysis/glycogenolysis within skeletal muscles not tissue hypoperfusion
Use with caution in patients with CAD
However clinical trials have not demonstrated worsened outcomes

Indications.text:
Epi versus norepi in patients with shock found that elevated levels of lactic acidosis or tachycardia in 13% of epi patients causes
[3]
Second-line agent in sepsis that should be considered after shock is refractory to other
vasopressors
2/2 increased number of adverse events that include tachydysrhythmias and lactate production
